discussion.content: A would only be for a single technician but in my places you have fellow technicians. Documentation assists all the technicians and it is best practice to maintain a working, searchable database of documentation to help all members of the team when an issue comes up.

comments.content: The technician ticketing system is tied in many times to a knowledge base for technicians. Rather, it can be tied in. When an incident happens you can search and pull up information about previous incidents in the knowledge base, in the same ticketing system.

discussion.content: Feel like A is the viable option

choices.B: Document the findings in the technician ticketing system.
choices.D: Brief upper management in a meeting regarding the findings.
choices.C: Document the solution in a user-facing FAQ page.
choices.A: Take personal notes for future reference.

questions.question_text: A technician was contacted regarding an issue affecting hundreds of users on a domain network. Which of the following would be MOST effective at remediating future issues through documentation?

choices.A: End the lsass.exe service running on the system.
choices.B: Uninstall and reinstall the antivirus program.
choices.C: Disable and rename the administrator account.
choices.D: Update the system with the latest security updates.

discussion.content: The is D, is wrong because to the best of my knowlege you can disable or rename widnows admin account
You might be able to disable the administrator account but it won’t disable admin privileges of lower level accounts.

I guess if you disable the Admin account there is no point renaming it.... I think it wants you to select C as (in CompTIA world) Windows updates help secure the system and prevent such exploits from working.

comments.content: Also, there could be other admins on the system. Disabling/renaming the Administrator account may not be enough. In other words 'C' is probably not a complete enough answer.

discussion.content: D is the right answer

comments.content: I agree with C. The question is very specific by asking how to "prevent potential privilege escalation attacks on the local system"...

discussion.content:
Answer is C. 

If it was referring to hardening the workstation overall, D would be correct. Make sure security updates are all up-to-date. But it specifically noted priv esc which directly correlates to someone accessing an admin account. So in regards to hardening against this attack specifically, you would disable and rename the account that would provide escalated priv.
C is correct
should this not be to "disable and rename the inbuilt admin account"? which is C. This would prevent anyone from being able to easily use the admin account

comments.content: Still not inof you need to secure it up to date because even if you are not the administrator you need to prevent an attacker from looking like a user.

questions.question_text: A technician is hardening a Windows workstation. One of the hardening requirements for the workstation is to prevent potential privilege escalation attacks on the local system. Which of the following steps should the technician perform to BEST meet this requirement?

choices.F: Use the local client certificate for server authentication
choices.C: Put the terminal server into the router's DMZ
choices.E: Block all unused ports on the LAN smart switch

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
changing the password and making it more challenging to crack it is always the first step

Selected Answer: AB
AB is correct.
(A) security by obscurity, used with SSH server to change port from 22 to 2022 for example.
(B) complexity hardens against brute force attacks against server.
(C) router DMZ is used in a home network not enterprise. DMZ makes the LAN more secure.
(D) this makes penetration available 24/7.
(E) Disabling (not block) ports makes network more secure & is a Cisco concept. 
(F) this makes it harder to RDP to LAN devices & doesn't protect server.

Why is this B and F? This is my reasoning...Option A is like changing the location of the door to your clubhouse. It might confuse some people at first, but if someone really wanted to find it, they could look around and find the door. Option F is like giving a special secret handshake to your friends. Only the friends who know this secret handshake can enter the clubhouse. This way, even if someone finds the door, they can’t get in unless they know the secret handshake. So, using the secret handshake (Option F) is a better way to keep your clubhouse safe than just moving the door (Option A). It’s a stronger way to make sure only your friends can get in.

Selected Answer: AB
A and B
the DMZ is correct because it's a terminal server, if it's going to be accessed from outside you want it outside the firewall

comments.content: C is most certainly wrong....the DMZ doesn't increase securiy in any way

discussion.content: Answer C is definitely wrong .The DMZ network itself is not safe. It enables hosts and systems stored within it to be accessible from untrusted external networks, such as the internet, while keeping other hosts and systems on private networks isolated.

Answer is A & B. Question asks to increase security on the SERVER.

C - DMZ is definitely not going to increase security of a server. 
D - Obvious. 
E - Nothing states anything refering to using a LAN smart switch. 
F - Will not increase security. 

A & B are the only logical answers that will increase security on a SERVER.

I fail to see how C and E go together.

If you were going to move the server into the DMZ you would also want to change the default access port to cut down on brute force attempts (A and C)

However we don't know what the intention of this server is, it may only be hosting an internal application, in which case there's no way you would want it in the DMZ. Also frankly if you needed external access to this server a more secure option would be to have a vpn concentrator in your DMZ and the server in the internal network.

I'm tempted to go with B and E just because C F and D would all seem to DECREASE security and there's little need to change a default port on an internal server.

comments.content:
I agree with kbarx11
Microsoft Windows Terminal Server is a core component of Windows Desktop products and Microsoft Windows Server that allows remote computers to connect to a Windows operating system computer using a remote terminal sessio

its a terminal server remember. so it would be for a bunch of thin clients in a public space. so people would not have to log on. putting the terminal server on the DMZ would make sense becuase then the public doesnt have the abilty to access anything on the main servers, and blocking all unused ports would mean even less ways of 'getting in' so to speak. this question confused the hell out of me until i reread it 100 times and noticed it said 'terminal'.

discussion.content: Answer is A and B

VPNs provide you with better overall security, improved performance, remote access, anonymity, and in some cases, cheaper tickets and rentals. Plus, they're blatantly affordable. If you're not convinced by now, it means you basically want companies, competitors, and hackers to have access to your data.

Pros of VPN: What are the advantages of using a VPN?
Secure Your Network. Without your knowledge, an application or website can keep track of your activity online. ...
Hide Your Private Information. ...
Prevent Data Throttling. ...
Avoid Bandwidth Throttling. ...
Get Access to Geo-blocked Services. ...
Network Scalability. ...
Reduce Support Costs.
The VPN allows the user's computer to act as a local client, even though the User is physically connected elsewhere
